info.title: enfore Promotions API
info.description:
enfore API for managing promotions and related objects

Sales vouchers represent a liability of the business against whoever owns the voucher.

The enfore platform supports three types of sales vouchers:
**gift cards**, **product vouchers**, and **category vouchers**.

tags.name: Sales Vouchers: Gift Cards
tags.description: Gift cards have a direct monetary value and can be used to pay for any kind of product/service (with some limitations due to tax laws).

tags.name: Sales Vouchers: Product Vouchers
tags.description: Product vouchers can be redeemed for a specific product only.

tags.name: Sales Vouchers: Category Vouchers
tags.description: Category vouchers can be redeemed for products of a specfic sales category only.

get.description:
Returns gift cards, sorted in ascending order by `issued_date_and_time`.
For gift cards without such a value, the timestamp of their import into the system is used instead.

parameters.name: org-id
parameters.description: ID of the organization whose data is being accessed.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description:
Defines the time starting from which objects are to be returned.
Objects with exactly this date are also returned - this means that the start of a left-closed interval is defined.
Timestamp in UTC. The date-time notation as defined by RFC 3339 (https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt), section 5.6, with the "Z" as time-offset. For example, 2017-07-21T17:32:28.123Z

parameters.name: to
parameters.description:
Defines the time up to which objects are to be returned.
Objects with exactly this date are not returned - this means that the end of a right-open interval is defined.
Timestamp in UTC. The date-time notation as defined by RFC 3339 (https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt), section 5.6, with the "Z" as time-offset. For example, 2017-07-21T17:32:28.123Z

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description:
Max number of objects to be returned per page.
Note that both the `items` as well as the `problems` arrays of the query response count towards this number to allow a simple,
consistent paging over all items (and problems) of a given timeframe.
If not given, defaults to `200`.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description:
Offset of items and problems of where to start the next page.
Similar to limit and offset in SQL, one would obtain the second page with `limit=10&offset=10`.
Note that this paging with limit and offset is within a time interval that is specified with `from` and `to`.
If not given, defaults to `0`.

parameters.name: number
parameters.description: When specified, only gift cards with the specified number are returned.

parameters.name: external_number
parameters.description: When specified, only gift cards with the specified external number are returned.

items.description: The gift cards contained in the sequence

id.description: The technical identifier of the gift card.

name.description:
The name of the gift card.
This usually is the name of the "source product".

number.description: The unique number of the gift card.

status.description: The possible status values for a gift card.

value.description:
The numerical value of the Money.
Must be in the range of -9,000,000,000,000 to 9,000,000,000,000 and may use up to 6 decimal digits.

unit.description: Represents a currency. Uses the ISO 4217 codes.

current_balance.description: A Money represents a monetary value (i.e., a currency and an amount), for example "120 EUR" or "2,500.75 USD".

tax.description:
A Tax represents a specific and unchangeable tax. Whenever a tax (rate) changes due to new legislation
or other reasons, a new Tax must be defined and used from then on.

For example, the standard VAT rates in Germany have been changed multiple times in the last 50 years:
* 01.01.1968 � 30.06.1968 = 10%
* 01.07.1968 � 31.12.1977 = 11%
* 01.01.1978 � 30.06.1979 = 12%
* 01.07.1979 � 30.06.1983 = 13%
* 01.07.1983 � 31.12.1992 = 14%
* 01.01.1993 � 31.03.1998 = 15%
* 01.04.1998 � 31.12.2006 = 16%
* 01.01.2007 � current    = 19%

For now, we only use the tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2007. But if, hypothetically, Germany would increase its
standard VAT rate to 21% on 1/JAN/2020, we would define a new tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2020 and use that from
1/JAN/2020 on.

put.summary: Update the activation status of an external gift card

parameters.name: org-id
parameters.description: ID of the organization whose data is being accessed.

parameters.name: gift-card-id
parameters.description: ID of the gift card

schema.description:
The possible activation statuses for a gift card.
They result in changes to the GiftCardStatus depending on the current balance:
- If ACTIVE, the sales voucher is activated (ISSUED, PARTIALLY_REDEEMED or REDEEMED)
- If DEACTIVATED, it's deactivated (DEACTIVATED).
- It is not possible to go to EXPIRED or CANCELED status.

201.description: Gift card activation status has been updated successfully

schema.description:
The possible activation statuses for a gift card.
They result in changes to the GiftCardStatus depending on the current balance:
- If ACTIVE, the sales voucher is activated (ISSUED, PARTIALLY_REDEEMED or REDEEMED)
- If DEACTIVATED, it's deactivated (DEACTIVATED).
- It is not possible to go to EXPIRED or CANCELED status.

tax.description:
A Tax represents a specific and unchangeable tax. Whenever a tax (rate) changes due to new legislation
or other reasons, a new Tax must be defined and used from then on.

For example, the standard VAT rates in Germany have been changed multiple times in the last 50 years:
* 01.01.1968 � 30.06.1968 = 10%
* 01.07.1968 � 31.12.1977 = 11%
* 01.01.1978 � 30.06.1979 = 12%
* 01.07.1979 � 30.06.1983 = 13%
* 01.07.1983 � 31.12.1992 = 14%
* 01.01.1993 � 31.03.1998 = 15%
* 01.04.1998 � 31.12.2006 = 16%
* 01.01.2007 � current    = 19%

For now, we only use the tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2007. But if, hypothetically, Germany would increase its
standard VAT rate to 21% on 1/JAN/2020, we would define a new tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2020 and use that from
1/JAN/2020 on.

get.summary: Iterate over the redemptions of a gift card.
get.description: Returns redemptions of the gift card sorted ascending order by `transaction_date_and_time`.

parameters.name: org-id
parameters.description: ID of the organization whose data is being accessed.

parameters.name: gift-card-id
parameters.description: ID of the gift card

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description:
Max number of objects to be returned per page.
Note that both the `items` as well as the `problems` arrays of the query response count towards this number to allow a simple,
consistent paging over all items (and problems) of a given timeframe.
If not given, defaults to `200`.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description:
Offset of items and problems of where to start the next page.
Similar to limit and offset in SQL, one would obtain the second page with `limit=10&offset=10`.
Note that this paging with limit and offset is within a time interval that is specified with `from` and `to`.
If not given, defaults to `0`.

parameters.description: ID of the organization whose data is being accessed.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description:
Defines the time starting from which objects are to be returned.
Objects with exactly this date are also returned - this means that the start of a left-closed interval is defined.
Timestamp in UTC. The date-time notation as defined by RFC 3339 (https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt), section 5.6, with the "Z" as time-offset. For example, 2017-07-21T17:32:28.123Z

parameters.name: to
parameters.description:
Defines the time up to which objects are to be returned.
Objects with exactly this date are not returned - this means that the end of a right-open interval is defined.
Timestamp in UTC. The date-time notation as defined by RFC 3339 (https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt), section 5.6, with the "Z" as time-offset. For example, 2017-07-21T17:32:28.123Z

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description:
Max number of objects to be returned per page.
Note that both the `items` as well as the `problems` arrays of the query response count towards this number to allow a simple,
consistent paging over all items (and problems) of a given timeframe.
If not given, defaults to `200`.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description:
Offset of items and problems of where to start the next page.
Similar to limit and offset in SQL, one would obtain the second page with `limit=10&offset=10`.
Note that this paging with limit and offset is within a time interval that is specified with `from` and `to`.
If not given, defaults to `0`.

tax.description:
A Tax represents a specific and unchangeable tax. Whenever a tax (rate) changes due to new legislation
or other reasons, a new Tax must be defined and used from then on.

For example, the standard VAT rates in Germany have been changed multiple times in the last 50 years:
* 01.01.1968 � 30.06.1968 = 10%
* 01.07.1968 � 31.12.1977 = 11%
* 01.01.1978 � 30.06.1979 = 12%
* 01.07.1979 � 30.06.1983 = 13%
* 01.07.1983 � 31.12.1992 = 14%
* 01.01.1993 � 31.03.1998 = 15%
* 01.04.1998 � 31.12.2006 = 16%
* 01.01.2007 � current    = 19%

For now, we only use the tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2007. But if, hypothetically, Germany would increase its
standard VAT rate to 21% on 1/JAN/2020, we would define a new tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2020 and use that from
1/JAN/2020 on.

Timestamp in UTC. The date-time notation as defined by RFC 3339 (https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt), section 5.6, with the "Z" as time-offset. For example, 2017-07-21T17:32:28.123Z

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description:
Max number of objects to be returned per page.
Note that both the `items` as well as the `problems` arrays of the query response count towards this number to allow a simple,
consistent paging over all items (and problems) of a given timeframe.
If not given, defaults to `200`.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description:
Offset of items and problems of where to start the next page.
Similar to limit and offset in SQL, one would obtain the second page with `limit=10&offset=10`.
Note that this paging with limit and offset is within a time interval that is specified with `from` and `to`.
If not given, defaults to `0`.

tax.description:
A Tax represents a specific and unchangeable tax. Whenever a tax (rate) changes due to new legislation
or other reasons, a new Tax must be defined and used from then on.

For example, the standard VAT rates in Germany have been changed multiple times in the last 50 years:
* 01.01.1968 � 30.06.1968 = 10%
* 01.07.1968 � 31.12.1977 = 11%
* 01.01.1978 � 30.06.1979 = 12%
* 01.07.1979 � 30.06.1983 = 13%
* 01.07.1983 � 31.12.1992 = 14%
* 01.01.1993 � 31.03.1998 = 15%
* 01.04.1998 � 31.12.2006 = 16%
* 01.01.2007 � current    = 19%

For now, we only use the tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2007. But if, hypothetically, Germany would increase its
standard VAT rate to 21% on 1/JAN/2020, we would define a new tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2020 and use that from
1/JAN/2020 on.

tax.description:
A Tax represents a specific and unchangeable tax. Whenever a tax (rate) changes due to new legislation
or other reasons, a new Tax must be defined and used from then on.

For example, the standard VAT rates in Germany have been changed multiple times in the last 50 years:
* 01.01.1968 � 30.06.1968 = 10%
* 01.07.1968 � 31.12.1977 = 11%
* 01.01.1978 � 30.06.1979 = 12%
* 01.07.1979 � 30.06.1983 = 13%
* 01.07.1983 � 31.12.1992 = 14%
* 01.01.1993 � 31.03.1998 = 15%
* 01.04.1998 � 31.12.2006 = 16%
* 01.01.2007 � current    = 19%

For now, we only use the tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2007. But if, hypothetically, Germany would increase its
standard VAT rate to 21% on 1/JAN/2020, we would define a new tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2020 and use that from
1/JAN/2020 on.

GiftCardActivationStatus.description:
The possible activation statuses for a gift card.
They result in changes to the GiftCardStatus depending on the current balance:
- If ACTIVE, the sales voucher is activated (ISSUED, PARTIALLY_REDEEMED or REDEEMED)
- If DEACTIVATED, it's deactivated (DEACTIVATED).
- It is not possible to go to EXPIRED or CANCELED status.

product_sales_price_and_quantity.description:
The set of information defining the price of a product.
A product's price is always relative to a specific quantity of the product.
For example, if a single bottle of water costs 1�, 5 bottles cost 5�.
Additionally, a given price might be including tax or not.
Therefore, the ProductPriceAndQuantity is a combination of a quantity, a price and a "price is gross"-flag.
